solutions.title: Dual Principal Model
solutions.shortDesc: AI assistants aren't just tools—they're first-class principals with their own authentication tokens, declared capabilities, audit trails, and access policies.
solutions.problem: Traditional auth models track users. But when an AI assistant makes a request on behalf of a user, you need to know: Who authorized this? Which assistant is executing? What capabilities were granted? What's the context?
solutions.solution: Every request in Symbia carries two principals: the user who authorized the action and the assistant executing it. Both are authenticated, both have declared capabilities, and both are audited.

details.title: User Principal
details.desc: Human identity with org membership and roles

details.title: Assistant Principal
details.desc: AI identity with declared capabilities and rules

details.title: Compound Token
details.desc: JWT encodes both principals with intersection of permissions

details.title: Audit Trail
details.desc: Every action logged with full principal context

solutions.title: Stream Control Semantics
solutions.shortDesc: Pause, resume, preempt, and hand off AI responses mid-stream. Real-time control without losing context or state.
solutions.problem: LLM responses stream over seconds or minutes. Users don't wait politely—they interrupt, correct, redirect. Traditional request/response has no concept of mid-stream control.
solutions.solution: Every streaming response in Symbia is controllable. Pause it, resume it, preempt it with new context, or hand it off to another assistant—all without losing state.

details.title: Pause
details.desc: Suspend streaming while preserving generation state

details.title: Resume
details.desc: Continue from exact pause point with context intact

details.title: Preempt
details.desc: Interrupt with new user input; assistant adapts mid-response

details.title: Handoff
details.desc: Transfer stream to different assistant with full context

solutions.title: Graphs, Not Code
solutions.shortDesc: Workflows are declarative data structures. JSON-serializable, version-controlled, runtime-mutable. Change behavior without redeploying.
solutions.problem: AI behavior is complex—routing, branching, fallbacks, handoffs. Expressing this in imperative code creates tangled spaghetti that's impossible to visualize, version, or modify at runtime.
solutions.solution: Workflows in Symbia are declarative JSON graphs. They're serializable, version-controlled, and runtime-mutable. Change behavior without redeploying code.

details.title: Visual Editing
details.desc: Design workflows in the Control Center graph editor

details.title: Hot Reload
details.desc: Update workflows without service restarts

details.title: A/B Testing
details.desc: Run multiple workflow versions simultaneously

details.title: Version Control
details.desc: Git-friendly JSON diffs for workflow history

solutions.title: Self-Documenting Services
solutions.shortDesc: Every service auto-generates LLM-optimized docs at /docs/llms.txt. Assistants can discover capabilities without human intervention.
solutions.problem: AI assistants need to understand your system to act effectively. Static documentation written for humans is too verbose, often outdated, and not optimized for LLM comprehension.
solutions.solution: Every Symbia service auto-generates LLM-optimized documentation at /docs/llms.txt. Concise, structured, always current. Assistants can discover and understand capabilities without human help.

details.desc: One-line purpose statement

details.desc: All routes with method, path, description

details.title: Request/Response Schemas
details.desc: TypeScript-style type definitions

details.desc: Concrete request/response examples

solutions.title: Multi-Tenant Native
solutions.shortDesc: Workspace isolation, tenant-scoped execution, and header-based context propagation. Every request carries organizational context.
solutions.problem: SaaS platforms serve multiple organizations. Each needs data isolation, but bolting multi-tenancy onto an existing architecture creates leaky abstractions and security risks.
solutions.solution: Symbia is multi-tenant from the ground up. Every request carries organizational context via headers. Data boundaries are enforced at the query layer, not the application layer.

details.title: Header-Based Context
details.desc: X-Org-Id propagates through all service calls

details.title: Query Scoping
details.desc: Database queries automatically filter by tenant

details.title: Workspace Isolation
details.desc: Assistants and workflows scoped to workspaces

details.title: Credential Separation
details.desc: API keys and secrets isolated per organization

solutions.title: Universal Integrations
solutions.shortDesc: Connect to any third-party system. Drop in an OpenAPI spec, point to an MCP server, or wrap a JS SDK.
solutions.problem: AI assistants need to interact with external systems—CRMs, databases, APIs. Building custom integrations for each is expensive and brittle.
solutions.solution: Symbia supports three universal integration patterns. Drop in an OpenAPI spec, connect an MCP server, or wrap a JS SDK. Assistants discover and use tools without custom code.

details.title: OpenAPI Specs
details.desc: Auto-generate callable tools from any OpenAPI 3.x specification

details.title: MCP Servers
details.desc: Connect to Model Context Protocol servers for standardized tool access

details.title: JS SDK Wrappers
details.desc: Wrap any JavaScript/TypeScript SDK as assistant-callable tools
